I stumbled on this channel by chance. I aggree with a lot of comments below: this is not only restauration, this is pure art! You make simple technical appliances a piece of technical art. I love how the small details of mechanics show out. I'm especially fond of how you improve on the original parts by removing sharp edges, excess casting marks and evenening out surfaces (though the sometime loose the original touch of the castin technique, but the painting result is much more pleasing). I'm astonished at the time and patience spent in restoring these unique and seldom parts, keeping historic parts alive and usesable.
I could imagine putting special specimen in a technical museum.
I terms of technical competence and craftmanship, you are definitively top notch and a real expert at what you to.
Keep on going.

Sir, I keep watching your restoration videos because I am fascinated with your skill and craftsmanship. You have a superior film editing and segment timing ability; you do not let anything drag on too long or make it to short to understand what you did; I have clicked off other videos for bad editing. 

I suggest that you start "autographing" your restorations in a discreet place. For example, "1st restored Oct 26, 2018; Munich, Germany, Your Name". In this way it marks it as your craftsmanship. This way when it is restored again in 137 years, the next restorer will know that he is working on a genuine "Your Name" and he too can sign it "2nd restoration. . . ." This will create a sense of history, continuity and personal achievement for each item you restore. My greatest technical skills are that I can turn a screwdriver and pound a hammer; this is why your excellence fascinates me. I am in search of excellence -- wherever it may be.

That's awesome that you screen printed the new dial, which is, in all likelihood, how the original dial was printed in the first place, but you should have vectorized the scan of the dial (i.e., manually trace the lines [and the numbers/letters if you can't find a matching font] in a vector program like Adobe Illustrator, CorelDRAW, or Inkscape) instead of using the scan to make your film positive. Using the raster scan to make your film positive is why your lines have irregularities/roughness to them. That will always happen if you don't use a perfect source, like a properly-made vector file, to make your film positive. You can use a raster program like Gimp or Photoshop too, as long as you recreate the dial's lettering and lines from scratch (the scan is simply not as good as recreating it from scratch with perfect lines, even if you do clean the scan up) and you do it at at least 600 PPI.

Never ever grease air tools. Grease and pressured air tend to have an exiting explosive reaction. When you compress a gas it creates heat, when you compress air you now have O2 and heat, add grease, you have fuel. Put that all in a confined space, you now have a pipe bomb. Safety tip, keep grease/oil away from your compressed air tools. Only oil where the tool is designed to have oil.

Just a suggestion, in 30 years of working in the industrial instrumentation field, I have learned to always use paste thread sealant on air users. It seems inevitable that even on properly taped joints, a tiny piece of tape will break off and fly through the system looking for that one orifice that it can stop up, and bring an entire plant to it's knees. This isn't a critical thing like that but I liked your video enough I thought I'd add what ever I could to it. Good going on the calibration by the way.

titolo e descrizione originale
"1950s Tyre Inflator - Perfect Restoration"
1950s Broken Tyre Inflator with Pressure Gauge Restoration - Ceccato.

In this video i'm restoring a broken italian tyre inflator with pressure gauge from the 1950s.

Like, comment, subscribe.

I found this tyre inflator with pressure gauge, which dessperetly needed a restoration. It was broken. Air was leaking everywhere, the handle wasn't working properly anymore and the pressure gauge didn't work either. This was definitely the most challenging restoration i did so far. I hope you like the result and the video.

Timestamps

00:00 preview and pretesting
00:59 disassembling
04:18 cleaning the parts with the partswasher
04:31 restoring the body
05:46 making a new bolt for the handle
06:11 restoring the handle
06:41 restoring the nuts
07:04 making new gaskets for the nuts
07:13 restoring the valve
07:47 making new gaskets for the valve
08:09 making a new glass for the pressure gauge
09:05 making a new gasket for the glass of the pressure gauge
09:22 making a new dial for the pressure gauge
11:27 the issue with the pressure gauge
12:03 making a distance disc for the pressure gauge
12:43 restoring the cover from the pressure gauge
13:14 making 10 new tiny bolts for the pressure gauge
13:47 restoring the case from the pressure gauge
14:42 restoring the tube with the valves
15:31 restoring the blue handle
15:46 making a new gasket for the pressure gauge
16:20 overview before assembling
16:52 assembling the body
18:33 assembling the tube with the valves
19:24 assembling and adjustment of the pressure gauge
21:42 showing off the finished product
22:47 final test

If you have any questions about the process, machines i'm using or other stuff, just ask me in the comments. I read them all and i try to reply as soon as possible.

Sorry for my bad english, it's not my language. I try my best to improve my technical english.

Subscribe for more of my content. I'm uploading videos about mechanical stuff, as new creations and buildings and also restorations. 

Thank you for watching :-)

I can't describe what I felt after watching this video.

I would go with "pure joy" but it wouldn't do it justice.
Makes me happy to see that there is someone out there who sees the beauty and purpose of old, rusty, damaged tools.

For a lot of people a "broken" tool like this isn't worth paying attention to...it would probably go straight into the dumpster.

But you my friend are different:

You see in the tool not what it is at this point in time but what it once was. It had a purpose, it served someone, or even a lot of people, well. It was a loyal companion, always there to do its job, always happy to be picked up and help.

I'm actually getting a bit emotional over here because of the fact, that there is someone like you out there. You find joy in returning those old, rusted tools to their prime time.

You give those tools a reason to be excited again when they are being picked up.

So yeah...this is probably what I feel after watching this video.

You go dude!

Cependant je reste persuadé qu'une restoration doit retrouver l'état d'origine, et non être «trop belle». Le gonfleur était un outil qui trainait par terre dans un garage, le polir comme un bijou est à mon sens excessif. Je verrai plutôt un travail de nettoyage des parties alu avec du «vapor honing» qui est du microbillage mélangé à de l'eau. L'eau lubrifie le sablage et donne des résultats magnifiques, comme neuf, mais avec une finition satinée comme à l'origine et non poli-miroir. De même puisque le verre n'était pas cassé pourquoi ne pas le réutiliser ?
Enfin c'est mon avis. Mais bravo pour la qualité de votre travail et les multiples talents mis en œuvre !

The extent of the shop available to you and your wealth of knowledge is beyond expectations. Like many others, I lost my shit when you screen printed that dial. At first I was appreciating the oldskool mechanical quality of this tool, clearly it has been made to be taken apart and worked on so it would last you a lifetime. But by the end of this video, I started to suspect that if you would have made it, it would be of an even higher quality. I mean simple pins to hold that beautiful dial in place to hide the pressure mechanism behind it? What if you need to service it again (as with all pressure gauges)? I bet the thought of holding it in place with pins wouldn't even cross your mind as you'd already be done making two beautiful custom screws to hold that dial steady. :)

A vast majority of youtube "restorations" are barely even repairs, removing rust with a bucket of evapo-rust, cleaning up the the surfaces, slinging some paint at it, and getting things just back to a functional state. This? This is absolutely a restoration. No doubt about it. The fact that you welded up the slot and re-milled it alone puts you in a whole different category to other youtubers, but to then machine new screws instead of just finding some that kind-of fit, buffing every surface and pin, screenprinting the dial, and other completely unnecessary but crucial steps to maximizing the quality of the final product. Very impressive work sir, you've re-set the bar. I'd say even for many of the well established restoration channels.

This came up in my suggested and I had a look expecting to click off in a minute or two... But actually you did an amazing job, especially compared to all the new channels popping up doing low standard "restorations". Was an absolute pleasure to watch, until the end when you ruined it all. The screws need to line up man. Another 1/16th turn either way on the screw that secures the handle, to make it horizontal or vertical. And decide on which angle you want, and make all the screws on the face align. Personally I would have them all perpendicular to the radius, such as the screws at marks 8 and 10 bar.

That is true attention to detail, and the only fault I could find.

That's the way I grew up, you did not have much, but ya cared for what you had. If it broke it got fixed. I studied and learned about everything I need to survive in this disposable world.  I've repaired an built millions of dollars worth of equipment and products for the average person to live in their perfect world. From processing equipment to sewer pumps, well pumps to orchard tractors,  food  processing machines to quarry  equipment. Container ships to aircraft carriers.  Even worked in a gold mine on process pumps that moved cyanide.  Being a repair contractor I've seen the better part of the U.S.. wouldn't trade it for anything.  It's not always a easy life,  but the average person never sees what it takes for them to do their normal 9 to 5  life.  The repairman works in the wet & cold sometimes for days on end to keep civilization on track.  people that ask what I do for a living, my reply is every time you flush the toilet, you can think of me.

Un recupero perfetto con lavorazioni "certosine". Ottima padronanza delle tecniche necessarie, senza escludere le ottime riprese. COMPLIMENTI sinceri e tutti meritati, anzi, non eguagliano la bravura e la passione profusa in questo "intervento". Scoprirti è stato bello e interessante, se mai potrò conoscerti di persona sarà un onore e un vero piacere. Ancora BRAVO davvero.
Una precisazione. il teflon andrebbe applicato in maniera diversa: come dire, in senso contrario ... andrebbe girato il rotolo .... più facile a farsi che ne spiegarlo. Si svolge mentre si arrotola attorno al pezzo, non come fai tu. Inoltre la superficie del filetto andrebbe leggermente grattata con i denti di una lama di sega da ferro evitando così che il teflon poi scivoli su filetto mentre si avvita il pezzo.
Sono finezze che hanno il loro perché e che non tutti conoscono, tu però sei bravissimo ugualmente (anche la creazione di un nuovo quadrante e in che modo) ... Chapeau !

Hang on! I've watched enough restoration videos to know restoration means grinding the hell out of something with an angle grinder. You do this with no regard to how much you are weakening the object you are grinding because you’ll fix this with the extremely thick layers of inappropriate paint.

So what’s all the measuring, and carefully polishing metal with lathe work of a truly different level? Then you spoil it further by the precision put into everything even the gauge's face? As for using true craftsmanship and an understanding of what you are doing...well you aught to be thoroughly ashamed of yourself. Acting like some sort of technical genius leaving your viewer in total awe should be banned from YouTube!

I’m subscribing, but next time I want angle grinder and Hammerite like the proper restorers on YouTube. I don't want any more of this being totally mesmerised all the way through of a phenomenal video.

Joking aside, that has to be the best 23 minutes 37 seconds of mechanical restoration I've ever seen! Your attention to detail and the effort you put into getting this exact was a wonderful thing to watch. Thank you for making this video and taking us on the journey with you.
